Friedman says most Americans know that if the Republican leadership in Congress ''really cared about the Cuban people,'' it would hold hearings on why the American policy for ousting Fidel Castro isn't working. We should debate not just why the policy isn't working, but why we should foster Mr. Castro's ouster at all.

In his April 28 column about Elian Gonzalez, Thomas L. Friedman says most Americans know that if the Republican leadership in Congress ''really cared about the Cuban people,'' it would hold hearings on why the American policy for ousting Fidel Castro isn't working. We should debate not just why the policy isn't working, but why we should foster Mr. Castro's ouster at all.

Should it be our policy to oust leaders of countries that do not pose a security threat? If Canada, Mexico and the European Union countries have normal relations with Cuba, why shouldn't we? What, if any, United States interests are served by our policy?
